Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Internet System for Networked Sensor Experimentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) and Machine Science Inc. propose to develop a web-based system for aggregating and sharing sensor data collected using a wireless communication system. The system would allow high school students and undergraduates to view, graph, analyze, and export data from individual sensors, and to combine data from multiple sensors to examine regional, national, and global phenomena (e.g., for STEM topics ranging from human health to environmental science and energy conservation).

The proposed project?s intellectual merit derives from its use of emerging wireless and web technologies to enhance student engagement and understanding. Recent advances in wireless communication, power management, and networking protocols have made it significantly easier and less expensive to gather real-time data from remotely installed sensors. At the same time, new Internet technologies have emerged for sharing and aggregating data from multiple sources. Notably, the project will make use of RSS technology, which transforms web content, such as blogs, message board postings, and syndicated news, into data streams that can be readily parsed and manipulated. Likewise, the project will leverage ?mashup? technology, which combines user-supplied data with the imagery and user interface of web services like Google Maps to produce hybrid tools of astounding power and versatility.

The scientific instruments and web system developed under the grant will be piloted in Massachusetts and then actively promoted nationally to ensure the project?s broader impacts. As the data set grows, it will be available for review and analysis by the entire web community. Open standards for data representation and transmission will be used, as appropriate. At the pilot stage, students will be recruited from racially diverse and economically disadvantaged urban communities, and encouraged to pursue research projects focusing on a variety of scientific problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the University of Massachusetts Lowell and a non-profit partner, Machine Science Inc., developed iSENSE--an on-line system for storing and sharing data collected by secondary school students and teachers in science experiments, environmental sampling efforts, engineering projects, surveys, and other classroom activities (www.isenseproject.org). The team also developed a sensor and GPS data-logging device, called the Portable iSENSE Network Point (PINPoint), which enables users to record geotagged sensor data and easily upload the data to the iSENSE web system. With a small seed grant from Google, students at UMass Lowell developed a series of apps for the Android operating system, allowing Android smart phones and tablet computers to be used for iSENSE data collection and visualization. 

Four multi-day summer workshops and three single-day trainings were held from 2008 to 2011 to help middle school and high school educators learn to teach with iSENSE. These events provided valuable opportunities to gather feedback from participants on the emerging web and data-logging technology and explore their ideas for teaching with iSENSE. Those educators who went on from the workshops to use iSENSE with their students received extensive on-site support from members of the project team, including both technology development staff and educational researchers. Observations and interviews conducted during these site visits constitute the core of the research data produced in the project.

Our research suggests that iSENSE is a useful technology for structuring classroom instruction, expanding the range of data-collection activities available to educators. Students are engaged by the iSENSE system’s combination of physical hardware, mobile technology, and web software. Importantly, students grasp the possibilities of using the iSENSE system, and this prompts them to pose their own science questions. At the same time, barriers to widespread adoption of iSENSE and similar technologies remain. Using iSENSE requires teachers to adapt to new ways of interacting with their students, with exchanges mediated by technology to a large degree. Moreover, significant scaffolding is required to support collaborative experimentation among schools, move science outside the classroom, and develop a community of learners.
